image.altText: Watercolour map of Australia showing low amounts of rainfall across the country with ocean in background.

props.synopsis: It was Peruvian fishermen, hundreds of years ago, who first noticed and named El Ni√±o. Little did they realise they had named one of the most consequential climate drivers on Earth. This is how it works.

title.children: Bushfire warnings downgraded, residents allowed out of Tasmanian tourist town

image.altText: Lynda Goymour with son Mitchell looking up a suburban street.

props.synopsis: A wheelchair taxi shortage continues taking a toll on members of the disability community in northern Tasmania, with a mum saying her son's health has deteriorated after having to cancel numerous specialist appointments due to the taxis' unreliability.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorians are set to learn the details of a long-awaited housing shake-up to address weak supply and soaring rents. Premier Daniel Andrews and his ministers met yesterday to endorse the first lot of reforms ahead of an expected announcement as early as today. The changes are expected to include an Australian-first consumer tax on short-term accommodation bookings with providers like Airbnb and Stayz. They're also expected to include incentives to build social housing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victoria set to reveal long-awaited housing shake-up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Where have these photos been all our lives? üòç Rihanna and A$AP Rocky have introduced their newborn son, Riot Rose, in a family photo shoot. The first public photos were shared by photographer Diggzy who captioned them "It's a FAMILY thing üí™". The reveal comes just over two months after Riot was born ‚Äî his name appears to be a reference to Rocky's 2023 track RIOT (Rowdy Pipe'n). The couple's first child, one-year-old RZA, also featured in the photos.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It's a family thing': Rihanna and A$AP Rocky share first photos of baby son Riot Rose

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hot and dry conditions are expected to persist across northern and eastern New South Wales today. Across the Greater Sydney and Hunter regions, winds will be stronger than previous days. They will combine with high temperatures and low humidity to cause the "extreme" fire danger. It comes on the back of the Bureau of Meteorology formally declaring an El Ni√±o weather event is underway. Total fire bans include Newcastle, Lake Macquarie, Port Stephens and parts of the state's Central West. Meanwhile, a severe weather warning remains in place for parts of Tasmania. Firefighters are continuing to battle a bushfire on the state's east coast that forced the evacuation of residents in Coles Bay overnight .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Extreme' fire danger warnings remain in place for parts of NSW
